Someone should be held responsible for what happened to us. Iaposm not going to use Hays Travel again. It was very stressful and I donapost want anyone  to go through the same thing. It just spoiled the holiday. Hays Travel has apologised to Michael and handed the couple £ as a gesture of goodwill. It says it was unaware of the issue until Michael called them from New York. A spokesman said: We were extremely sorry to hear of the mix-up regarding Mr Hulme’s hotel arrangements. We arranged for him to receive a full refund, plus compensation, as quickly as possible. story: Pensioner unable to shut his eyes for three YEARS after botched cosmetic surgeryWARNING GRAPHIC CONTENT: Pete Broadhurst, , from Birmingham, had £, cosmetic surgery to try and deal with puffy cheeks but now has to tape his eyes shut to sleepPete Broadhursts £, cosmetic surgery has left him in a living hell Image: SWNSByFiona JacksonKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsA pensioner claims botched surgery means he hasnapost been able to close his eyes - for nearly THREE YEARS. Pete Broadhurst, , splashed out £, on a cosmetic procedure to fix his puffy cheeks in . But, even after corrective surgery, his left eye is still permanently open - causing him constant problems. Pete has to tape his eyes shut when he sleeps and use drops eight times a day to prevent them drying out. He says he looks frightening as his eyes stay open even when he wants to close them - and claims his appearance has cost him relationships. Pete, a retired painter and decorator, is speaking out now to warn others about the dangers of surgery.  He said: Getting on the bus one day a man said, aposmy God, whataposs happened to your face apos. I was already feeling down it just made it worse. Now Iaposm only worried about getting my eyes comfortable. Itaposs gone beyond how I look. I just want relief. I want to tell others to be careful because it can ruin your le. Peteaposs problem started in , when he had a class  occlusion to fix a tooth problem which led to him having enlarged cheeks. He said: I had puffy hamster cheeks. Years ago I was in a relationship with a girl and we had two children and she was leaving me. I said, aposwhy are you leaving when weaposve got everything  Look at how lucky we are.apos And she said, aposgo look in the mirror, thataposs why Iaposm leavingapos.  After two further relationships where his insecurities about his looks grew, Pete decided he wanted to get corrective surgery. So, the father-of-two, from Four Oaks, Birmingham, decided late in  that he would go in for a procedure. He approached BMI The Priory Hospital, who quoted him £, to undergo a neck lt, under eye blepharoplasty and a rhinoplasty that would help reduce his cheeks. And, on January , , he underwent the nine-hour procedure, and was discharged the next day. Pete said: I looked like Iaposd been beaten up. It was horrendous, and I couldnapost close my eyes. Iaposm being sick all through the night and in my sleep. The day after the surgery I wished Iaposd never gone. Pete claims he was vomiting and couldnapost pass urine but just took these as the normal after effects of surgery.  The following Monday, after leaving the hospital, Pete had a catheter fitted, thinking initially it was to do with his prostate. But he now believes that his problems passing urine were due to spending an elongated period of time under general anaesthetic where he couldnapost go to the toilet. He ed to the hospital two weeks after the surgery to get the stitches removed, and told the medics that his eyes were very irritated and watering. But Pete claims that they told him all was normal and these side effects would pass by themselves. He then went to the Good Hope Hospital on March ,  to have a routine prostate exam. But the doctor noticed his damaged eyes - and he was referred to Birmingham and Midland Eye Centre. There they told him his eyes weren’t closing fully when he blinked or slept causing him irritation - a common complication of eyelid surgery called ectropion. However, the doctors there couldn’t treat him as he had the original surgery privately, so he ed to BMI. His surgeon arranged for a free corrective surgery at BHI Parkside for a skin graft to help the skin in his cheeks meet his eyelids.  He had the hour-long surgery on May , . But, more than two years later, Pete claims he still canapost fully close his left eye - and the right one is completely shut. He said: My eyes were distorted, I could barely see at all. Sheaposd lted my left eyelid up and my right eye had a blinker in the corner. It never improved again. I was unable to see and at night I still had to tape it shut. Pete has been prescribed eye drops to take eight times a day, and was told to microwave a towel to wrap around his eyes for when he sleeps. His vision is now so poor he canapost drive a car or make out peopleaposs facial expressions, and has had to give up his hobby of shooting as he canapost see the target.All private hospitals have since refused to provide any further surgery as they could exacerbate his vision issues, and the NHS had a year-long waiting list.This has meant Pete felt forced to go abroad, resulting in a £, lower eyelid blepharoplasty at the Clinic Mono in Turkey.He saw the surgery advertised in the newspaper as where Katie Price goes, and is due back there later this year for a follow-up procedure.Pete said: My left eye is still open today. Whoever you trust, even a top surgeon, please be careful because it can ruin your le. A BMI Healthcare spokesman said: We can’t comment on the detail of inidual cases, but we are committed to the highest standards of patient safety and care quality and are investigating this matter thoroughly. The surgeon in question is currently suspended as we are mirroring an NHS trust suspension. Lindsey Sharp, from BHI Parkside, said: BHI does not provide healthcare. It provides space to NHS, private consultants and other healthcare professionals to undertake services they are qualied to provide. The surgeon who performed Peteaposs surgery at BHI Parkside declined to comment as she cannot share confidential information about patients. news uk-news prince-charles-invites-meghan-harry-"Prince Harry files claim over police protection for familyByRussell MyersRoyal Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsPrince Charles has offered an olive branch to his son Harry by inviting his family to stay with him when they next visit the UK, royal sources have revealed. The Prince of Wales has expressed his firm wish to spend quality time with his grandchildren, having not seen Archie since he was six months old and not ever meeting the Duke and Duchess of Sussex’s baby daughter, Lilibet Diana, who was born in June.The offer of bringing the family together for the first time since Harry and his we Meghan decided to quit their royal roles and set up home in Calornia was made by the heir in the lead up to Christmas, it is understood.But Charles’s good natured plan, in an attempt to heal the rt between him and his son, has been thrown into doubt after Harry suggested awould come at “too great a personal risk” due to his security situation. It was thought that Harry and Meghan would certainly make an effort to attend events to celebrate the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee in June.What do you make of our exclusive story  Have your say in the comment section Harry is understood to have told family members he would attend a memorial service for his late grandfather Prince Philip at Westminster Abbey, which is planned for April.However, it has emerged that the Duke of Sussex claims he is “unable tohome” after a decision following his exit from the royal family stripped him of his right to personal security provided by the Met Police. Harry, , has since decided to sue the British government by applying for a judicial review against the decision, which could see him face the Home Office at the court. Royal sources have confirmed the Prince of Wales has held several “good natured and enjoyable” video calls with his son, Meghan and the children during the past few months. One source said: “The Prince of Wales has been saddened that he hasn’t had the opportunity to spend time with his grandchildren, which he really does miss. “He is a fantastic grandfather and loves playing the role immensely and it’s certainly fair to say he feels there is something missing from his le without the ability to get to know Harry’s children. “This is something he is hoping to remedy which is why he made the gesture for Harry, Meghan and the children to stay with himthey wanted to, whenever they may come home for a period of time. “In the meantime there has been a series of good natured and enjoyable calls between them all which is something the prince very much looks forward to.” In the calls Charles, , has made it clear to his son of his wish to spend quality time with two-year-old Archie and seven-month-old baby Lilibet. Harry’s relationship with his family is understood to have been fractured following his exit from The Firm in , and subsequent decision last year to appear with Meghan, , in a tell-all interview with US chat show queen Oprah Winfrey. The couple beamoned their treatment by the family, with Harry accusing his father of cutting him off financially and further claiming a senior member of the family made racist remarks about the colour of his unborn children’s skin. Sources close to Charles have told The Mirror that despite reports of the two not speaking, Charles and Harry have been on “a journey of rediscovery” in terms of their relationship.  One said: “The Prince of Wales has spoken to his son frequently in recent months. He loves him very much, as he does both his children, and he looks forward to them being able to spend time together in the near future.” Harry and Meghan, now live in an £million mansion in the millionaires’ playground of Montecito, Calornia, have not spent any time out of the United States since their move in . Harry is however also expected to attend the Invictus Games, which he founded, in The Hague, the Netherlands, in April.Since their exit from the family they have signed deals worth an estimated £million with streaming giants Netflix and Spoty, with the capability to earn hundreds of millions of dollars having become “financially independent”.Clarence House did not comment. The Duke of Sussex’s unprecedented move of threatening to sue the government is both breathtaking and utterly baffling. Those in royal circles have almost universally questioned the play at hand, not only in its nature but equally in execution. True enough, with his background in the military and his position in one of the most famous families in the world – and celebrity lestyle – Prince Harry and his family are arguably high profile targets. title: pub landlord renames boozer the
story: Pub to be renamed The Lying B****** in response to Boris Johnson parties scandalDaniel Davies, who owns what was once the James Atherton pub in New Brighton, near Liverpool, has suggested a new name for the venue, which has previously been called The Three B***endsDaniel’s pub was previously named ‘The Three B***ends’ Image: Getty ImagesByAlice Peacock:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A pub landlord with a history of changing the name of his boozer to poke fun at ious political scandals is now to rebrand his venue as “The Lying B****** in a dig at Boris Johnson.Daniel Davies owns what was once the James Atherton pub in New Brighton, near Liverpool. He suggested a new name for the venue as Johnson is facing furious calls to resign, following reports of at least  parties across Downing Street, Whitehall and Tory HQ while millions suffered under lockdown rules. Johnson is accused of attending at least four of the events.Covid-bereaved families have blasted the bashes, and No’s repeated attempts to obscure the truth before the PM finally apologised.Daniel’s pub was previously named The Three B***ends and featured a collage of Boris Johnson, Matt Hancock and Dominic Cummings with bells on their heads in October ,reports.  It was said to be a tongue-in-cheek protest at the Government’s handling of the situation when the Liverpool City Region was placed into Tier Three lockdown, forcing pubs to close. The pub was once again renamed in November , called “The Two Helmets” following Mr Cummings’ departure from Downing St. The image outside of the pub showed the PM and his former health secretary wearing hardhats, as the landlord protested about continuing restrictions on the pub-trade. Daniel pointed out that both Mr Cummings, the PM’s former chief advisor, and Mr Hancock, quit their positions within weeks of the signs going up. “Next name change for the pub ” his tweet asked.  “The first was The Three B***endsNext was The Two HelmetsSo. Two down one to go!” Daniel said the first rebrand was prompted by the government blaming the leisure sector for the spread of Covid-. He previously said his business had been “decimated” and their lack of action had compounded the problem. He said: “Westminster’s further decision to pick and choose which types of venue may open, based on those serving meals for example, is mind-boggling. ‘Whilst the renaming of the pub is clearly tongue in cheek, as far as I’m concerned the gloves are off and ministers need to understand the gravity of the perilous situation they have placed us in.  This is a town that finally feels like it’s on the up and we need funding immediately to protect our businesses and support our staff. Top civil servant Sue Gray is probing a range of the Downing Street parties, spanning May  to April , and is expected to publish a report within days. At the time of all these gatherings, indoor socialising was banned to control the spread of the virus.But ultimately the Prime Minister will get to decide himselfhe has breached the Ministerial Code. Johnson is reportedly planning to force out a string of top staff to save himself in what has been dubbed Operation Big Dog.Speaking to the media today, Conservative party chairman Oliver Dowden said the Prime Minister is remorseful about allegations of Covid rule-breaking and would seek to “address the underlying culture in Downing Street”.There had been failings in No , he admitted, though he denied it was a resigning matter for Boris Johnson. title: queen alienate prince harry continues
story: Exclusive: Queen may alienate Prince Harryhe continues to act like spoilt child, says expertPrince Harry says hes unable toto the UK with Meghan Markle, Archie and Lilibet due to security risks, but a row has broken out over what protection he should be allowedMeghan and Harry with the Queen in  Image: Getty ImagesByZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments The Queen will be irritated by Prince Harryaposs threat to take the Government to court over his security, an expert has claimed.The Duke says heaposs unable toto the UK with we Meghan and their children Archie and Lilibet as it isnapost safe without specialist police protection. The family lost their taxpayer-funded security when the quit the royal family in  and use a private alternative for their new lives in the US. Heaposs wants pay for police assistance when heaposs in the UK - in line with the coupleaposs plan to become financially independent - but the Home Office has rejected this. Harry has now applied for a judicial review against the decision.Ingrid Seward, author of Prince Philip Revealed and Editor in Chief of Majesty magazine, tells the Mirror his latest move wonapost have gone down with the Queen - who is currently dealing with the fallout from Prince Andrewaposs legal case. She explains: Prince Harryaposs threat of legal action against his grandmothers government will not sit kindly with her. The Queen does not like being threatened. Even though the threat is not directed at her personally, it is a threat that comes under her jurisdiction. It will make her annoyed and very irritated. She has no desire to alienate the Duke and Duchess of Sussex , butthey continually behave like spoiled children trying to get their own way, she will be forced to do so. As youngsters both Harry and William knew exactly how their Police Protection Officers operated. They became close to them. They were together every time they left home. One even sat outside the classroom. They were friendly, efficient and unobtrusive. No wonder Harry wants that kind of protection for his we and children. But he is very unlikely to get it. Many have been left wondering what Harryaposs request will mean for his future trips to the UK, with many hoping to catch a glimpse of the Sussexes during the Queenaposs Jubilee celebrations in the summer. Ingrid says: Harry is due back to the UK in the Spring for the service of thanksgiving for the le of his grandfather, Prince Philip. He will be protected during this official engagement at Westminster Abbey. ButHarry and Meghan choose the celebrations of the Platinum Jubilee weekend to make an entry into the UK, as things stand at the present, they will not have round the clock Scotland Yard protection - unless they are with other members of the royal family. If for instance they appeared on the Buckingham Palace balcony they would be afforded all the security necessary along with everyone .But when they drive home to Frogmore Cottage, their private bodyguards will be responsible for them.Once there, they are the responsibility of the Windsor Castle security. The police at Windsor recently apprehended an intruder who had climbed over the security fence. If the Sussexes don’t get their own way as regards their demand for police protection, they may decide not to come to the UK. In spite of the fuss their security risk is low. What they want is protection from photographers trying to get pictures of them and their children. The more they shield their children from public gaze the more of a target they will become. Harry’s father should tell them to let the world see Archie and Lilibet’s faces. After they are his grandchildren too. It is not up to the -year-old Queen to tell Harry how to behave. What would this do for the already tense relations within the family  If it means she never gets to meet Lilibet, it will become Harry and Meghan’s problem for the rest of their lives. And that would be very sad. title: queens scottish home vandalised paedo
story: Queens Scottish home vandalised with paedo graffiti as police launch probePhotos taken yesterday morning show Her Majestys Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh behind an outer wall daubed with graffiti reading, paedo home and burn Tory scumThe Queens Edinburgh palace has been sprayed with the words, paedo homeByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  Police are investigating after a vandal graffitied paedo home on the wall outside the Queen’s Scottish residence.The outer walls of the Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh were pictured spray-painted with two defamatory remarks yesterday morning.One image shows paedo home sprayed in large white letters along one wall, while the palace can be seen in the background. Another image shows the words burn Tory scum written along the same wall in similar style. The graffiti comes just days after a US court ruled that Virginia Giuffre, who claims that Prince Andrew abused her when she was , could proceed with legal action against him.Prince Andrew has strongly denied the claims. Buckingham Palace released a statement last Thursday saying that The Duke of York would be ing his military titles and royal patronages back to the Queen.Rory Richmond, a law student from Glasgow, posted a photo on Twitter Sunday of the graffiti aimed at the Conservatives.He wrote: “This was photographed at Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh earlier today.“We must condemn and confront the mindless acts of vandalism and hatred.” The tweet has received over  likes and has had dozens of comments and retweets.Social media users were outraged by the graffiti. One wrote: “Appalling vandalism. There are no excuses for it at all, itaposs criminality whether or not it suits your political party of choice.In a statement shared with The Mirror, a Police Scotland spokesperson said: “Police received report of vandalism on an external wall at the Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh which happened between pm on Saturday,  January and am on Sunday,  January, . “Enquiries are ongoing and anyone with information should contact police via , quoting incident number  of  January.” The prince has been reeling after he was stripped of his military titles and royal patronages just  hours after being told he must face a civil trial. The move means Andrew has been completely removed from official royal le and he now have to face his future as an ­ordinary citizen. The Duke of York was informed that he will no longer use the title of His Royal Highness in any official capacity by the Queen on Thursday. The decision was made after hours of deliberation between senior members of the Firm. But the summit is said to have not been straight-forward, with his lawyer left in the car park and the Prince left stunned by the outcome. Among the key revelation from the meeting, was news of a united front from Prince Charles and Prince William, who were reportedly of the view that the Duke of York has presided over a complete and utter disaster.” Andrew is also said to have been unaware about the plans, with sources describing him as shell-shocked at the move. title: unpleasant new omicron symptom makes
story: Unpleasant new Omicron symptom that makes you feel nauseous and causes vomitingAmong the wide range of symptoms being linked to the Omicron iant of Covid-, some can be easier to spot than others. Nausea and vomiting are thought to be some of the easiest to separate from the common coldOmicron can cause vomiting in some cases, according to experts Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByHarry Thompson:,  Jan | commentsOmicron continues to rip through the nation, with tens of thousands of new Covid cases being reported each day. While previous iants of the virus have been easy to spot, Omicron is somewhat stealthier, its symptoms blending in with seasonal illnesses like the flu or a common winter lurgy.Older strains, like the Delta iant, tended to see their symptoms focus around shortness of breath, a new and continuous cough and a fever. Meanwhile, Omicron has seen symptoms like a scratchy throat, fatigue and muscle ache rising to the fore as some of the more commonly experienced signs. However, there are some symptoms that arenapost as common amongst these annual nuisances that could make spotting the presence of Omicron in your system easier. Is nausea and vomiting a sign of Omicron  Nausea and vomiting could be a sign your body is working against a Covid- infection, according to Good Housekeeping.They report that healthcare experts are seeing an uptick in the number of people picking up Omicron and having uncontrollable vomiting and nausea as some of their primary symptoms. This makes the symptoms relatively easy to spot compared to a common cold, which is unlikely to cause such a reaction from the body. Good Housekeeping reports that the trends being spotted by researchers who have been looking into the iant between December and January are mapping the virus as attacking the upper respiratory tract. Experts have also warned that Omicron sufferers could still experience regular covid symptoms. It is worth bearing in mind of course that vomiting and nausea donapost necessarily mean you have covid - they are very common symptoms for a wide range of dferent medical conditions. However sickness be an indicator of Omicron in some scenarios.What are the symptoms of Covid- According to the US-based Centers for Disease Control, or CDC, a number of symptoms are now being considered more common. The CDC has updated its list of Covid  symptoms to reflect the presence of Omicron as one of the major iants in the USA. They are: Fever or chills Cough Shortness of breath or dficulty breathing Fatigue Muscle or body aches Headache New loss of taste or smell Sore throat Congestion or runny nose Nausea or vomiting Diarrhoea Meanwhile, the UK-based NHS still lists the three most prevalent symptoms from the previous iants.These are a high temperature, a new cough and a loss or change to your sense of taste and or smell. title: what bbcs tv licence how
story: What is BBCs TV licence, how much does it cost and will it be scrapped Funding for the BBC TV licence is set to be frozen for the next two years, following which it could be scrapped altogether. Heres what you need to know about paying for your TV licenceTV licence fees will be frozen at current rates for the next two years Image: Getty ImagesByMalvika Padin:,  Jan | comments The government has announced some major changes to the BBC TV licenceaposs funding model, with funds to be frozen at current rates until . There have been a series of discussions between culture secretary Nadine Dorries and BBC chiefs about how the broadcaster will be funded going forward.The culture secretary said the next announcement concerning the BBC’s licence fee “will be the last” as a new funding model is being considered for when the latest deal expires in .Here’s everything you need to know about the TV licence including why you need to pay it and what happensthe BBC gets rid of it.What is the BBCaposs TV licence fee and why do we have to pay it  TV licensing is a form of taxation which is used to raise revenue that funds the BBC. The money raised from the licence fee pays for BBC shows and services - including TV, radio, the BBC website, podcasts, iPlayer, local journalism and apps.Watching live TV without a licence is against the law and is punishable by a fine of up to £, as well as prosecution. The TV licence fee was set by the government in  and changes every year on April . Currently the rates are £ a year, and £. for black and white televisions. With Nadine Dorries considering new ways to fund the BBC, the fee is set to be frozen at the current rates until April .She wrote on Twitter : This licence fee announcement will be the last.The days of the elderly being threatened with prison sentences and bailfs knocking on doors are over. Time now to discuss and debate new ways of funding, supporting and selling great British content.Is the TV licence fee being scrapped and what will happenthe BBC gets rid of it  The BBC was expecting a rise to its licence fee to help pay for its expenses and programming during the current period of inflation. And had it taken place, the licence fee would have risen to £ a year.But the freeze at current rates of £ is set to last for two years, after which new ways to pay for the public broadcaster will be discussed again. The licence fee is expected to exist until  December , after which the government is considering introducing a subscription model to the television fee. This has been made to appeal to Conservative backbench MPs over ways to mitigate the rising cost of living, according to the Sunday Times. is a little bit gloomier this morning, it could be because today is Blue Monday.Some claim it is supposedly the most depressing day of the year. Thereaposs no doubt the month of January can be hard for many. There are some who look at is as a time for fresh starts, a time to embark on new endeavours and challenges.But for many itaposs completely miserable. Our bodies are still recovering from Christmas over-indulgence, our wallets are feeling the pinch and many have put strict restrictions on themselves. The warmth of summer is still far away, and although weaposre not in lockdown still, weaposre in the middle of a worldwide pandemic. But why is today, of all days, known as Blue Monday  Here is everything you need to know. What is Blue Monday  Blue Monday is supposedly the most depressing day of year, due to a number of factors. It usually falls on the third Monday of January every year, although it can also fall on the second or fourth. The first Blue Monday was marked in  when the idea was conceived by le coach and happiness consultant Dr Clf Arnall.  He was asked by travel firm Sky Travel, who anted to promote their winter deals, to work out he most depressing day of the year.Clf published a formula to work it out using factors such as the weather, debt, the amount of time elapsed since Christmas and since we failed New Yearaposs Resolutions, as well as general feelings of low motivation.The psychologist believed this formula could be used to predict when people would be poking trips to sunny holiday destinations. Although originally a PR invention, it is now an annual event. Is Blue Monday really the most depressing day of the year   Since coming up with the formula, Dr Arnall has since urged Brits to refute the whole notion of Blue Monday. He told The Dailyin  that it is not particularly helpful to put that out there and say ‘there you are’,” going on to describe Blue Monday as a self-fulfilling prophecy. Despite being picked up by PR companies all over the world, the formula has also been debunked by several members of the scientic community. Many have suggested there is no way you could assign numerical values to factors such as weather. Stephen Buckley, mental health charity Mind’s head of information, previously said: “There is no credible evidence behind the concept of a most depressing day of the year. In addition, recently collected data has has shown that the most unhappy period of January tends to fall later in the third week.According to HappyOrNot, the makers of the smiley face consumer feedback terminals found in airports, in  it fell on Wednesday .However, this wasnapost found to be the most unhappy day of the year as a whole. title: woman didnt spot new banksy
story: Woman didnt spot new Banksy graffiti on side of her house until seeing it onlinePeggy, who lives in Bristol, said she did not realise the famous graffiti artist had decorated the side of her house until she read about it on the internetA potential new Banksy appears on Marsh Lane in Bristol Image: BPM MEDIAByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA woman has told how she failed to notice a new Banksy painting which popped up on the side of her house in Bristol. Peggy, who did not give her surname, said she did not notice the world famous artist had graffitied her home until reading about it online.The painting shows a man in a balaclava using a crowbar to ply open a piece of wood which covers up a previous Banksy piece.The original graffiti shows a small child catapulting a sea of red roses into the air. It appeared in February  in Barton Hill, but was vandalised the following day. Vandals scrawled BCC w**** across the mural which was subsequently boarded up with plastic sheeting placed over the flowers. Peggy told Bristol Live how she did not spot the new addition to the graffiti because she does not tend to walk in that direction from her house.She said she did not hear anybody creating the new piece, although she did hear somebody painting the first artwork from inside her home. Banksy confirmed the original artwork was his the day after it appeared, but he is yet to claim the latest addition. Peggy said regardless of who did the work, she does not believe Banksy is just one person but a collective.  How  would they be able to do it so secretly  she said. She recalled how Banksyaposs first piece went up just before Valentineaposs Day when a cheeky spectator pinched some of the flowers from the display, knocked on her door and tried to sell them to her. Hannah Baker attended appointments and undergone surgical procedures for abdominal pain and bleeding in hospital. But she was distraught after her requests for a smear test were denied because was under  at the time. And now she is unable to have children because she has had cervical cancer. Cervical screening is available to women and people with a cervix aged  to  in England. But Hannah was diagnosed with the disease in March  when she . Now , she instructed specialist medical negligence lawyers at Irwin Mitchell to investigate her care and whether her cancer could have been diagnosed sooner. She is hopeful for a family after lawyers secured a settlement to fund her surrogacy.Frimley Health NHS Foundation trust, carried out an internal investigation and recommended any woman, irrespective of age, who is undergoing cervical cautery, should have a cervix biopsy of the before having treatment.Following legal submissions, the trust has now agreed an undisclosed six-figure settlement but has denied liability. Hannah underwent surgery to safeguard her oies for future fertility treatment before having chemoradiotherapy, radiotherapy and brachytherapy. However, the cancer treatment has left her unable to conceive. The settlement will fund surrogacy as Hannah and her partner Joe Allaway, aged , look to start a family. Hannah has now joined her legal team at Irwin Mitchell in supporting Cervical Cancer Prevention Week and the importance of women having smear tests. Mike Burke, , a metal detectorist, had been walking past a potential treasure trove but he was never allowed to dig it up as his we, Julie, had forbidden him.But one day she decided to replant the garden so gave Mike special permission to scour through the area for gold - and he seized the opportunity, as Cornwall Live reports.He didnapost expect to find anything, so was amazed when he pulled out a gold ring, believed to be a Roman intaglio ring, dating back to around the st or nd century AD. What do you think about Mikeaposs impressive find  Let us know in the comments...Mike, from St Just, Cornwall, said: I don’t normally have permission to go metal detecting in my front garden, because my we’s got a lot of flowers out there. Next month when she starts planting seeds again, I won’t be able to do it again, so it was now or never. First Mike found a two pence coin from the ‘s, then a halfpenny from the same decade, and a tin teddy bear that looked like it had been part of a baby’s rattle, each item as worthless as the next. But then, he got a solid hit on his metal decetor so he started digging.  He continued: Around six to  inches down, I noticed a little fleck of gold – well, something that looked like gold. I didn’t knowit was an old bottle top or something because I find them all the time. But when I pulled it out, it was a gold ring. Every day I look at this and I still get a shiver, you know, I just can’t imagine that I found something like this. story: Eerie last photo taken by British woman washed away by Tonga tsunami before waves hitAngela Glover is thought to have been swept away when she was hit by huge waves on one of the islands of Tongas west coast, while trying to save dogs with her husbandAngela Glovers last Instagram post showed the red sky and eerie silence Image: thegloverfits InstagramByKelly-Ann MillsNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A British woman who is thought to have died in the Tonga tsunami made a heartbreaking final post on social media, before the danger hit.Angela Glover is believed to have been swept away when she was hit by huge waves which crashed into an island on the countryaposs west coast.Shortly before the tsunami happened the -year-old posted a picture of red skies on Instagram, saying she had witnessed a few swells as authorities warned of a tsunami risk in the Polynesian archipelago, which is made up of  islands.She wrote: “We’ve been under tsunami warnings today...everything’s fine... a few swells ....a few eerie silences. Her photo shows the entire sky lit up red as she looked out over a calm ocean. Desperate family members had appealed for help finding Angela Glover, but a body was today found in the search for her. Her brother said she had been attempting to rescue dogs with her husband when huge waves battered the island, where she had lived since .  Angela, who ran a dog sanctuary in Tongaaposs capital, Nukuaposalofa, was swept away as the island was hit by ft waves on the west coast of Tongatapu, the countryaposs main island. Her husband James was able to cling on to a tree, and it is believed he later discovered Angelaaposs body. Speaking outside the family home in Sussex, her brother Nick Eleini said the family was devastated by the tragedy. “She was beautul. She was a ray of sunshine, he said.  She would just walk into a room and lighten the room up and she loved her le, both when she was working in London and then she achieved her le’s dream of going to work in the south Pacic. “She always wanted to swim with whales - that was a childhood ambition and that is what drove her to Tonga but she loved her le there and we are so proud of her achievements in Tonga with both her and James starting a business and creating a le there are her charity work with Tonga Animal Welfare Society. She was so committed to it.“She loved animals and dogs particularly.The uglier the dog, the more she loved it. We would laugh at her when she sent us these photos on Facebook of dogs she had rescued. She was a lovely girl and she was the centre of our family.We’re just broken.” He said Angela had been washed away with four or five dogs who she was walking at the time. The couple were housesitting a home on the west coast of the island. In a statement Mr Eleini added: “Angela and James loved their le in Tonga and adored the Tongan people, in particular they loved the Tongan love of family and Tongan culture. Family friend Donna Head, posted on Facebook : “The worst news possible has been confirmed by family members. Our Ange did not survive the Tonga Tsunami.“I have no words other than I’m utterly heartbroken and numb. May our beautul friend rest in peace. Ange, I will look out for your mum, I promise. story: NASA discovers new Jupiter-sized planet which is  times bigger than EarthThe gas giant was found by Tom Jacobs who was checking Nasa data from the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite and was confirmed by two academicsDubbed TOI- b, the planet was found by Citizen Scientist Tom Jacobs Image: NASA JPL-Caltech R. HurtByAntony Thrower:,  Jan | commentsA new planet with three times the mass of Jupiter has been discovered in the galaxy. Dubbed TOI- b, the planet was found by Citizen Scientist Tom Jacobs using data collected by Nasa’s Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite . The gas giant orbits its stars in just  days- compared to Jupiter which takes around  Earth years to travel around our Sun. The discovery was reported in the Astronomical Journal. Tom found TO having taken part in the Planet Hunter initiative which looks at the collected data. He spotted something irregular in February  and flagged it to two scientists, who later confirmed the find. He said: “Discovering and publishing TOI- b was a great group effort demonstrating that professional astronomers and seasoned citizen scientists can successfully work together.  “It is synergy at its best.” Scientists say the planet is around  lightyears away from Earth and has around  earth masses of elements heavier than hydrogen and helium. Around , exoplanets have been confirmed with billions more suspected to be in our galaxy. Paul Dalba, from the University of Calornia, Riverside, added: “The manual effort that they put in is really important and really impressive because it’s actually hard to write code that can go through a million light curves and identy single transit events reliably,” “This is one area where humans are still beating code.” It comes as an asteroid bigger than any building on Earth is set to soar past the planet tomorrow. It has been named and is more than a kilometre wide at , metres- making it bigger than the worldaposs tallest building the Burj Khala in Dubai which is  metres . However, it poses no threat to Earth and when it passes it will still be more than five times the moonaposs distance from the planet. title: new pentagon office investigate ufo
story: New Pentagon office to investigate UFO sightings around the world launchedThe Unidentied Aerial Phenomena programme was launched after a number of videos were released by the Pentagon of pilots spotting unidentied aircraftThe office will establishthere is a potential security threat from what is seen in the skies. Image: Bettmann ArchiveByAntony Thrower:,  Jan | commentsThe US Government has launched a new office to look into reports of UFOs from around the world. The move was signed into law just before the turn of the year and aims to establishthere is a potential security threat from what is seen in the skies. Experts will then work to establishthey came from a foreign force - or from a galaxy far, far away. Senator Kirsten Gillibrand said: “Our national security efforts rely on aerial supremacy and these phenomena present a challenge to our dominance. “The United States needs a coordinated effort to take control and understand whether these aerial phenomena belong to a foreign government or something  altogether.  The new Unidentied Aerial Phenomena programme was launched after a number of high profile videos were released by the Pentagon - many including US military chasing targets pulling off impossible manoeuvres and speeds. The move has upset many ufologists who believe the truth about possible visitors have been hidden from the masses for decades.Ron James, a spokesman for the Mutual UFO Network, said: “We donapost see that this means new resources will be dedicated to the matter.“We believe that considerable resources have always been dedicated to the matter at some level inside deep government and industry.” It comes as a UFO spotter who monitors the International Space Station’s live feed claimed to have proof of aliens’ existence. Scott Waring, who runs the website UFO Sightings Daily, said: “Watch this live space station footage taken today and you will see a close up of a huge sphere UFO rising up in earth’s orbit. “I and others have seen such UFOs orbiting Earths moon, but this event is a very rare one to see orbiting Earth. news world-news speedy-border-collie-zooms-after-"Border Collie runs all the way around edge of field to get ballByBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Jan | commentsBorder collies are undeniably one of the most intelligent working breeds - from herding sheep, to even learning names of their toys. And while some dogs might enjoy a quick game of fetch, others don’t realise when their owners have thrown the ‘invisible’ ball.But Tipsy goes the extra mile - quite literally - to chase her beloved ball.When her owner Jessi Burk, from London, in Canada, showed Tipsy her ball, she stopped dead in her tracks, paws poised and ready. Jessi threw the orange and blue ball over the other side of the sheep fence, and Tipsy - who’s been trained not to go over or through the fence - set off in a sprint in the opposite direction.  Taking the long way around, Tipsy ran through the gate, down the path and around the trees to retrieve her ball, ready for another throw. Other dog owners have shared how their dogs would have behaved in the same situation - and they’re vastly dferent to Tipsy’s marathon around the farm. One said: “My malinois would simply bulldoze the fence.” Another added: “My Doberman would stand at the fence and bark at the ball… for hours.”  One suggested tying string to the ball and pull it back when it almost gets there to seethe collie would run all the way back around. The two-year-old dog isn’t the only sheepdog to offer the internet a good giggle in recent months, either. Lucy Jones’ short-coated border collie is a talented herding dog, but had everyone in stitches after ‘pulling the wool’ over their eyes.In a TikTok video viewed nearly a million times, the collie sits perfectly still in the sheep barn, surrounded by his woolly workmates.But the dog is wrapped up in sheared sheep wool with just his little head poking out, hoping that no-one will notice that he’s an imposter. And where, farm dog Marshall loves his job so much, he herds whatever he can get his paws on - including his favourite football. His owner, Lisa Alekna, shared an adorable video of the dog stalking a ball in the garden whilst patiently awaiting for instructions from the shepherdess. title: tonga volcano aerial photos show
story: Tonga volcano: Aerial photos show island split in two by tsunami after eruptionThe underwater volcano erupted near the Pacic nation of Tonga and the extent of the damage can now be seen from space after it wreaked havoc on SaturdayNow the true extent of the damage can be seen from spaceByLaura SharmanFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsShocking images show the aftermath of an underwater volcano which erupted in the South Pacic Ocean on Saturday.Satellite images have revealed the extent of the damage after the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha’apai volcano erupted, with the devastation visible from space.The event triggered a tsunami and sent waves crashing into homes on the island, which was blanketed with toxic ash. The Red Cross said it was preparing to respond to what it called the worst volcanic eruption the Pacic has experienced in decades. Up to , people could have been affected by the tsunami, according to Katie Greenwood of the charity. One British woman was reported missing after trying to save her dogs with her husband and getting washed away by a wave. Angela Glover, who runs a dog rescue shelter on the island, was swept away with the animals while her husband James managed to hold onto a tree, according to New Zealand state broadcaster TVNZ. Tsunami warnings and evacuation orders were also triggered in neighbouring countries, including Japan and the east coast of Australia. Hunga-Tonga-Hunga-Haaposapai has erupted regularly over the past few decades but the impact of Saturdayaposs blast was felt as far away as Japan and the United States. Australia and New Zealand sent surveillance flights on Monday to assess damage in Tonga, isolated from the rest of the world. Initial reports suggest no mass casualties took place form Saturdayaposs eruption and tsunami, according to Australiaaposs Minister for the Pacic Zed Seselja. But Australian police had visited beaches and reported signicant damage with houses thrown around.  We know there is some signicant damage, and know there is signicant damage to resorts, Mr Seselja said adding that Tongaaposs airport appeared to be in relatively good condition. Surveillance flights will assess the situation in outer islands where communication is completely cut off. Tongaaposs deputy head of mission in Australia, Curtis Tuaposihalangingie, asked for patience as Tongaaposs government decides its priorities for aid.The nation is concerned about the risk of aid deliveries spreading Covid- to the island, which is currently free from the virus.We donapost want to bring in another wave - a tsunami of Covid-, Mr Tuaposihalangingie said. When people see such a huge explosion they want to help.  He went on to highlight how Tonga diplomats were also concerned by some private fundraising efforts and urged the public to wait until a disaster relief fund was announced. Any aid sent to Tonga would need to be quarantined, and it was likely no foreign personnel would be allowed to disembark aircraft, he said. The eruption of the Hunga-Tonga-Hunga-Haaposapai volcano triggered a tsunami on the shores of Tonga and cut off phone and internet lines for the entire island. International communication has been severely hampered by damage to an undersea cable which could take more than a week to restore. Australia and New Zealand were assisting with satellite calls, he said.  Telephone networks in Tonga have been restored but ash was posing a major health concern, contaminating drinking water. Most people are not aware the ash is toxic and bad for them to breath and they have to wear a mask, Tuaposihalangingie said.The Haaposatafu Beach Resort,  miles outside the capital Nukuaposalofa, was completely wiped outaposapos, the owners said on Facebook.The family that manages the resort had run for their lives through the bush to escape the tsunami, it said. The whole western coastline has been completely destroyed along with Kanukupolu village,aposapos the resort said. Two people drowned off a beach in Northern Peru due to high waves caused by the tsunami. More than a day after the eruption, countries thousands of kilometres to the west have volcanic ash clouds over them, New Zealand forecaster WeatherWatch said. Early data suggests the eruption was the biggest blast since Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines  years ago, New Zealand-based volcanologist Shane Cronin told Radio New Zealand. This is an eruption best witnessed from space, Cronin said. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: long covid recovery diary
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowOur hearts go out to everyone involved with the Nancy Glen tragedy.For the grieving families, the many people who valiantly tried to save the boat, everyone involved in the search for and recovery of the trawler and many more besides the ordeal of re-living the events of four years ago cannot have been easy.The ultimate outcome of the Fatal Accident Inquiry must be to help avoid such tragedies from happening again.The evidence given was technical, traumatic and deeply sad. There were many contributing factors according to the sherf, some of which would have been avoided with the crystal clear benefit of hindsight.As the sherf noted, the owners took pride in their vessel, kept it well maintained and considered it to be a safe boat. They were managing it little dferently to many others up and down the Scottish coast.But, crucially, no stability rules applied to boats like the Nancy Glen at the time of the accident.Duncan MacDougall was an experienced fisherman who knew these waters well and,it could happen to his boat, there is an obvious need to raise awareness to prevent such devastating accidents in future.

title: neil-hastings-leaves-gala-new-full-time-role-football
story: GALA Fairydean Rovers have announced the appointment of Martin ‘Jimmy’ Scott and Stevie Craig as their new management team until the end of the season following the departure of Neil Hastings to an undisclosed full-time role in football.Scott has been with the club for six months as first team coach and then Assistant Manager and is relishing the opportunity to take charge of the Lowland League outfit.He has appointed former Aberdeen player, Steven Craig, as his Assistant Manager and he will join the club this week.Club Chairman, Ryan Cass, added: “Three seasons ago we lost our way a little and lost our identity, it was so important we got that back. When Neil was appointed, he knew how important it was for Gala to play a certain way. His philosophy matched the club’s which was really exciting.“When the club decided to appoint Neil there were a few people outside the club that were very surprised as we finished in th place the season before but we knew that we got the right man for the job to bring back that identity and produce a team that the town could be proud of.“Since then we have gone from strength to strength and it has been the most successful period of the club’s history with a th place league finish and progressing to the third round of the Scottish Cup this year narrowly being defeated by League  contenders Annan Athletic.“I can’t thank Neil, the coaching staff and the players enough over the last few seasons and wish him all the best for the future. It didn’t surprise me when a club from the top-flight came calling as his coaching skills are second to none but most importantly as a person he is a great guy that wants to constantly learn and develop as a coach.“He has built a tremendous team spirit here at Gala which hasn’t gone unseen as the season tickets sales have been on the rise for the last two seasons.“The club wishes him good luck to not only our now ex-manager but to our friend and no doubt he’ll progress even further in the game..remove“We also want to wish Martin Scott and Steven Craig along with coach Colin McCall all the very best for the rest of the season.”

title: hastings-thanks-board-players-volunteers-support
story: Neil Hastings has left Gala Fairydean Rovers with ‘fond memories’ and has thanked the board, players and volunteers for their support during his time at the club.Hastings took over at Netherdale in the summer of  and made an immediate on the club with his professionalism, ambition and passion.He led Rovers to their highest league finish last season and everyone at the club wish him well in his new full-time post in the game.Hastings said: “Firstly, I would like to take this opportunity to thank the Chairman and the Board for their belief and trust in giving me my first managerial post back in May . They have continued to support and help me during my time at the club and for that I will be forever grateful.“Secondly, I would like to thank everyone behind the scenes at the club. At Gala this group is not a huge number and all of them are volunteers and at any level there is a lot of time  work that must be put in to get games on.“Washing strips, setting up goals, running turnstiles and hospitality, are all jobs that need to be done and both the players and I appreciate it.“Finally, I need to thank all of the players and every member of staff who have been at the club during my time. Please believe me none of them pay their mortgage from being at the club but their commitment  the sacrices they have made have been second to none.“I believe we currently have a fantastic group of players and staff who I have enjoyed working and spending time with!“In football there are many ups and downs and during my time at the club this has been no dferent. We have had positive results and disappointing results and performances, but the most frustrating thing is we haven’t been able to complete a full season during my time due to each season being prematurely finished due to covid.“I leave a fantastic club with good people who have good morals  beliefs. I leave with fond memories and friends for le. Thanks, and take care.”.removeClub Chairman, Ryan Cass, added: “I can’t thank Neil, the coaching staff and the players enough over the last few seasons and wish him all the best for the future. It didn’t surprise me when a club from the top-flight came calling as his coaching skills are second to none but most importantly as a person he is a great guy that wants to constantly learn and develop as a coach.“He has built a tremendous team spirit here at Gala which hasn’t gone unseen as the season tickets sales have been on the rise for the last two seasons.“The club wishes him good luck to not only our now ex-manager but to our friend and no doubt he’ll progress even further in the game.”Hastings will be replaced by his assistant Martin Scott.

title: westruther-council-planning-chiefs-overruled-house-bid
story: ELECTED officials have overruled the council’s planning officers after backing a proposal near a Borders village due to “exceptional circumstances”.The applicant, Donald McLeod, sought planning permission in principle to build a house close to Westruther with “specialist facilities” to accommodate the family’s specic health and welfare needs.Scottish Borders Councilroad officials objected to the development due it being unsafe for pedestrians to walk between the village and the proposed site.But members of the local authority’s planning and building standards committee supported the applicant at a meeting on Monday , with Mid Berwickshire councillor Donald Moffat describing it as “the right thing to do”.Council leader Mark Rowley, of the Conservatives, took the “very rare” step of calling in the application.Speaking at the meeting he said: “I initiated the call in after becoming aware of the McLeod family’s very unique challenges and the equally unique opportunity to mitigate them here on this site thanks to the generous support of neighbours.”The leader, who is also a Mid Berwickshire councillor, added that the house would “keep the family at the heart of their community”.According to Barry Fotheringham, SBC principal planning officer, the community council and seven healthcare professionals gave their support to the house proposal.But SBC planning officials recommended that the application should be refused due to pedestrian safety concerns, as well as the potential for “a signicant adverse impact upon the composition and quality of the landscape character”.A report published ahead of the meeting states: “Whilst acknowledging the applicant’s personal circumstances, there are no material planning considerations that would support the erection of a dwelling in this particular location, and there are no known extenuating circumstances or other material considerations, which indicate support for this development as an exception from the Local Development Plan. Regrettably, the principle of development is not considered acceptable in this location.”.removeIt adds: “The planning authority understands the applicant’s circumstances and need to find alternative, fit for purpose family accommodation that meets their very specic needs. Unfortunately, their very specic personal circumstances are not material to the assessment of this application and cannot be taken into account when determining the acceptability, or otherwise, of the proposed development.”However, at the meeting Mr Moffat, of the SNP, moved a formal proposal to approve the plans which was seconded by Hawick representative Clair Ramage.He said: “The family want to stay in the community where they have got a support mechanism. It’s important in cementing a local community together and stopping rural depopulation.“These are definitely exceptional circumstances. In pure planning terms I’ve heard what has been said and normally you wouldn’t take certain things into consideration.“I don’t often disagree with the planning officers [but] I would quite happily approve this in principle because it’s the right thing to do.”
